dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: Hi friends! Welcome to Digipalz Headquarters, where we monitor cyber threats across the globe. My name is Robotoro. I’m an artificial intelligence robot and cybersecurity expert designed to help you solve missions and understand the online world.

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: It's a tough job, but luckily I have you, to help my pals solve missions. Speaking of the Digipalz, here's Luna!

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: You know how much we love you, Robotoro. Thanks to you, Milo and I get to keep a pulse on what is going on in the cyber world.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: When you send us on missions, you give us the chance to help others who need support.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: We work together every day to solve missions that help people around our community. The best part is that we get to work with you, the agent behind the screen, to help us solve these missions.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t we tell our new agent here where we are and what this super cool room is?

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: Allow me! This is our home base, Digipalz Headquarters. From here, I monitor all the digital threats across the world. When there is a problem that needs our help, I task the Digipalz to solve the mission.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: What’s the goal behind each mission?

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: Every time we start a new mission, I’ll give you a Mission Brief, which is essential information you’ll need for your work ahead.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: These missions empower us to stay safe in the online world.

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: And don’t forget the most important part: the cyber threats you are solving are based on true stories that happen in the real world, too. What you learn in the missions will help you stay safe.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Good point, Robotoro. These missions are important life lessons. You can follow the same steps we take to help others in your life, too!

welcome.title: Cyberbullying
welcome.welcome_message: We start each mission, by reading a true story. They may be upsetting to read at times, but it is important to understand why each mission you solve is important. The story you are about to read for today’s mission demonstrates the impact that cyberbullying can have on a victim.

content.title: Charley's Story
content.content:
Charley was 12 years old when she started getting bullied online.
She never quite fit in at school. She was friendly, but different - and there is absolutely nothing wrong with that. However, Charley wanted to find friends that shared her interests, so she went online to make friends, looking for people who liked the same music and hobbies she did. She created an Instagram page about her favorite band, and it felt good to be herself. Charley started meeting others online who shared her interests. For the first time, she felt seen and accepted.
But then kids from school found the page.Instead of cheering her on, they began mocking her — first with jokes, then with cruel comments. They teased her about how she looked, called her names like "fat" and "ugly," and even told her to "go die." Even people she didn't know — total strangers — began posting hurtful things.
When one fake account got reported, the bullies made another. It felt never-ending.

Charley couldn't escape it. At school, people whispered and laughed. At home, her phone lit up with mean messages. What used to be her safe space became a constant reminder of the things people said about her. She felt anxious all the time, checking her phone day and night to see what was being said. She felt embarrassed, angry, and completely alone.
Eventually, it started affecting her school life. Some of her friends stopped coming to school because they were being bullied too. Charley began skipping school and didn't want to go at all. She felt like no matter where she was, she was being watched, judged, and targeted.
She said what hurt the most was that many of the bullies acted nice in real life, but online, they became someone else. It made her feel like she couldn't trust anyone.

 Charley's story shows how real and harmful online bullying can be. It didn't just hurt her feelings... it affected her health, her learning, and her ability to feel safe anywhere.
This kind of bullying happens more than you think. In fact, 1 in 3 kids experience cyberbullying. That means it could be happening to someone in your class — or even to you.
But there's something you can do about it.
If you're being bullied online: It's not your fault. Tell a trusted adult right away. You do not have to face it alone.
If you see someone being bullied: Speak up. Report it. Show kindness. It could mean everything to that person.
If you're tempted to make fun of someone online: Pause. Ask yourself how you'd feel if it happened to you. Your words and actions matter, so be kind online and offline.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Hi everyone. I’m Mr. Azabuki, the school guidance counsellor. That was a challenging article to read, and it is understandable if you feel affected by the story. If you or someone you know is experiencing bullying, talk to a parent, teacher, or school counsellor. Every student deserves to feel safe at school and online. Ready to start your mission?

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Robotoro, what’s the emergency?

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: There's a spider in here and I am scared of spiders.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: You do know that spiders can climb don't you?

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: There it is! It's on the computer, I can see it. Eeew! And all those hairy legs!

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: What's the spider doing?

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: It looks like It's building a website!

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Robotoro we have important work to do. You deal with the spider. We’re heading back to Mr.Azabuki’s office.

azabuki_check.title: Mr. Azabuki Check In
azabuki_check.message: Hi everyone. I’m Mr. Azabuki, the school guidance counsellor. That was a challenging article to read, and it is understandable if you feel affected by the story. If you or someone you know is experiencing bullying, talk to a parent, teacher, or school counsellor. Every student deserves to feel safe at school and online. Ready to start your mission?

mission_brief.title: Mission Brief
mission_brief.description: Cyberbullying is when someone uses technology to harm, threaten, or harass another person. This could happen through social media, text messages, online games, or websites. There are different forms of cyberbullying and it’s important to understand how it can affect students like you. Recognizing these behaviors is a crucial step in taking action and supporting students who might be affected.

mission_brief.title: Mission Brief
mission_brief.description: Rumors are going around Red Valley Elementary School that a student has been cyberbullying several classmates. Let’s uncover who it is and what happened. I will share important information along the way about the online world. Your mission awaits!

mission_tasks.title: Mission Tasks
mission_tasks.important_info: Read the following mission tasks carefully – you’ll be quizzed later!

tasks.title: Task 1
tasks.description: Define cyberbullying and identify its various forms.

tasks.title: Task 2
tasks.description: Understand how to effectively handle the experience of being cyberbullied using techniques like stop, screenshot, block, and reporting.

tasks.title: Task 3
tasks.description: Recognize the importance of reporting cyberbullying incidents to a trusted adult and learn what to do.

tasks.title: Task 4
tasks.description: Develop strategies to support peers who are being cyberbullied and become an active ally.

tasks.title: Task 5
tasks.description: Explore the psychological and social reasons behind bullying behavior.

dialogues.speaker: mr_spivak
dialogues.text: Hey Milo and Luna. Thank you for stopping by on such short notice.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Your call sounded urgent.

dialogues.speaker: mr_spivak
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it is. Our school's policy has been breached, and we need your help getting to the bottom of it. We've been getting reports of... let's call it 'unsavory' behavior in our school's online chatrooms.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Yikes, it sounds like you need our help.

dialogues.speaker: mr_spivak
dialogues.text: We take online bullying very seriously. This student has done their best to conceal their identity. Can you help us figure out who is behind this?

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Everybody likes to joke around and have fun with their classmates online. However, once a little playful banter crosses the line into bullying, it needs to be taken seriously.

dialogues.speaker: mr_spivak
dialogues.text: Here's a copy of our school chatroom policies you can review for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Spivak, we’ll see what’s going on in the chatrooms.

dialogues.speaker: mr_pasternak
dialogues.text: Well, good afternoon Digipalz, my good friends.  I'm very happy to see you both again.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Hey! It's good to see you too, Mr. Pasternak! Our favourite technology teacher.

dialogues.speaker: mr_pasternak
dialogues.text: I've heard you've come to help us with our chatroom bully problem. This is very good!

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: A bully is using the school chatroom. What should we be looking out for?

dialogues.speaker: mr_pasternak
dialogues.text: Let's see. There are different kinds of inappropriate behaviors to look out for. First, there is inappropriate language.

dialogues.speaker: mr_pasternak
dialogues.text: Secondly, hate speech or intimidation. And finally, threatening to share photos without the owner's permission.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: I see. That can be very serious.

dialogues.speaker: mr_pasternak
dialogues.text: Indeed. Take a look through the chat history, and see what you can find. Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Ummm... Mr. Pasternak?

dialogues.speaker: mr_pasternak
dialogues.text: Yes, Luna, what have you found?

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: These messages are not appropriate. Did you see the message threatening to post a photo of Katie in her underwear? That one really concerns me - we should escalate this.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Yes, on top of all the other disturbing examples, like hate speech, intimidation and threats.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Okay, Milo, why don’t you go see Principal Finley. I have somewhere I need to go first. Meet me outside afterwards – we have to talk to Katie.

dialogues.speaker: principal_finley
dialogues.text: Welcome Milo, please make yourself comfortable. What brings you into my office, dear?

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Principal Finley, I'll cut right to the chase. There is some CRAZY stuff going on in the school's chatroom.

dialogues.speaker: principal_finley
dialogues.text: Hmmmm, can you be more specific, Milo?

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Someone named ‘Hockey_291’ in the school's chatroom is violating the bullying policy. They’re threatening to post pictures of one of your students in their underwear.

dialogues.speaker: principal_finley
dialogues.text: Oh, that is serious! We must find out which student is behind this. Threatening to share revealing photos without consent violates our school policy.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Do you think we could call customer support from Chatroom Technologies to see if they can help us track this bully down?

dialogues.speaker: principal_finley
dialogues.text: That’s a great idea Milo! Can the Digipalz take the lead on this?

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Of course! We'll get to the bottom of this, Principal Finley.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Hey, are you Katie?

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: Ughhh, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Hi Katie. I’m Luna. I saw the messages in the school chatroom...

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: Seriously? People have been teasing me about this all day. I don't know who it is, or how they got a photo of me... in my underwear... But, it’s destroying my life right now.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Katie, I'm not here to tease you, I’m actually trying to get to the bottom of this. I also think you should talk to someone about this.

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: Like who?

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: You should talk to the school's guidance counsellor, Mr. Azabuki. He's very kind and understanding.

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: No way! Enough people know already! Besides, what good is he going to do?

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: I think talking to a supportive, trusted adult will help you cope with this. Let's go together, Katie.

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: Ughhh. Okay. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: Hey Mr. Azabuki, Luna suggested I come talk to you. Someone in the school chatrooms has been threatening to share embarrassing photos of me.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Thank you for trusting me Katie. You did the right thing by coming to talk to me. Do you have screenshots that you can share with me?

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I remember you taught us that when someone starts to attack us online, we need to stop responding, screenshot the message, block the bully and seek out help.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: That's absolutely right, Katie. I am so sorry you are going through this, and I'm going to do everything I can to help you. Can you show me the messages?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: These chat messages are incredibly alarming Katie. I can only imagine how upset you must be. Students who are being cyberbullied show all sorts of emotional and physical symptoms.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Yeah, like headaches and throwing up.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: You might feel lonely, helpless or ashamed. This may cause you to withdraw from school, even your friends.

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: I can’t sleep. I don’t feel like eating. I don’t even want to go to school... this person is threatening to post pictures of me in my underwear for everyone to see.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: There are many different symptoms that appear when you are being bullied. Digipalz team, your task is to sort the emotional versus physical symptoms in this next mini game.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Being a victim of bullying is certainly very painful. Most bullies attack others as a way to make themselves feel big, strong, or in charge. But deep down, they feel weak or insecure.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Really? I never thought about it that way.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Messages like this are often done 'for fun’. Bullies want to be popular. When I see language like this, I see an individual who is begging to be accepted and looked up to by their peers! Unfortunately, in the mind of the bully, the easiest way to make oneself popular is to make someone else look weak!

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: You're saying these bullies just crave attention?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Indeed. We all want to be liked. That's human nature. But, we cannot resort to hurting others to make ourselves feel more popular.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: It's our responsibility to help put an end to this behavior. What should we do next?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: First, Katie, I want to make sure you’re doing okay. It's normal to feel overwhelmed and scared when there is someone targeting you at school or online.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: It is not acceptable for anyone to make you feel unsafe, you must know that it is not your fault. You have done nothing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: He’s right Katie. This is not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: And you haven’t done anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Often the hardest part of these situations is talking to a trusted adult. However, it is really important that students report incidents like this as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: So what should I do?!

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Let’s call Robotoro, he’s an expert at this!

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: I have a question: what if my friend is being bullied? How do I help them?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: It can be hard to witness a friend being bullied and it is normal to want to help. But consider how you are responding and ask yourself if your response is helping the situation or worsening it.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: How do we know if we are helping or making it worse?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Well, there are two ways you can respond. The first way is to be ‘reactive’. This means that you are acting quickly based on your feelings without thinking first. If you are seeing your friend being bullied, you might feel really angry right away and want to yell at the bully or say something mean back.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: I can relate to that for sure.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: It's completely normal to feel those strong emotions! But responding this way is kind of like knocking over a glass of water when you're upset - it creates an even bigger mess to clean up.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: What is the second way?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: The second way to respond is called using 'emotional intelligence.' This is like being a detective of your own feelings. When you use emotional intelligence, you notice your feelings first - like feeling angry or upset when someone is being bullied - but you don't let those feelings be the boss of what you do next.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: How do we respond with emotional intelligence?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: You pause, take a deep breath, and choose a smarter way to help. This takes practice - just like learning any new skill! The cool thing is that when you respond with emotional intelligence, you have much more power to actually fix the problem. You're in control, not your feelings.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: Hmm… maybe we should practice.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Great idea, Luna. There is a resource I like to provide to students. It's a game called "How Would You React?"

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Well Let’s see it!

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: The directions are simple - when you are presented with a scenario, select a response based on how you would react in that moment. I'll guide you along the way.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: You all did so well.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: Sometimes I amaze even myself.

dialogues.speaker: luna
dialogues.text: This is about Katie, remember?!

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: I've got one more task for you. I want you to think about three adults in your life whom you feel comfortable talking to. If you are being threatened, bullied, targeted, or made to feel scared or unsafe, these are the adults you should talk to.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: One quick question, what do you mean by a trusted adult?

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: This can be a parent, guidance counsellor, teacher, relative, or even an older sibling. To complete the exercise, type three names into the bars provided.

dialogues.speaker: mr_azabuki
dialogues.text: Well done.

dialogues.speaker: milo
dialogues.text: You run a tight ship here, Mr. Azabuki. There’s still a bully to catch, so we’re off to the Computer Lab.

dialogues.speaker: katie
dialogues.text: Thank you, Luna, for bringing me to Mr. Azabuki’s office. I kind of feel better about this already.

dialogues.speaker: robotoro
dialogues.text: Wait, before you go, can you try out the “Block the Bully” game I’ve created? Here it is.
